Key Match Events: Bowden Francis had a chance to throw a no-hitter but lost it in the ninth inning again, this time to Francisco Lindor's home run.
The Mets blew the game wide open in the ninth, adding five more runs off the Blue Jays bullpen to win 6-2.
Pre-Game Insights: Francis had the chance to become only the second Toronto Blue Jays pitcher to throw a no-hitter, but twice, in an eerily similar fashion, Francis' chances to write his name in the history books were thwarted by a leadoff home run.
Post-Match Reflections: Despite losing the no-hitter, Francis was a good sport and received a standing ovation after eight fantastic one-run innings with a strikeout, a walk and two hit batters.
The Blue Jays' manager John Schneider said, 'I don't like to mess with a chance at history' so like last time, Francis had the ball until he gave up a hit.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Francis is ending the season on a historic run and positioning himself as a piece of the 2025 rotation.

The two near-no-nos are more evidence in the growing case file that Francis is a legitimate big-league starter, despite a slow start to his season that saw him bumped from the Opening Day rotation after two starts and later briefly sent down to the minors.
Others: Francis has gone 4-1 with a 1.26 ERA over his last six starts, and his 0.40 WHIP is the lowest mark over a six-start span in MLB history.
Francis has won honours such as MLB Player of the Week and Player of the Month.
